Title: Single Ventricle Reconstruction Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: The Single Ventricle Reconstruction trial aimed to compare outcomes of two shunt types in patients with single right ventricle lesions undergoing the Norwood procedure.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial included 393 participants with single right ventricle lesions, recruited from multiple centers. Participants were randomised to receive either a modified Blalock-Taussig shunt or a right ventricle-to-pulmonary artery shunt. The primary outcome was hospital length of stay (LOS) at the stage II procedure, measured in days. Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes. Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Results: A total of 393 participants were randomised, with 196 receiving the modified Blalock-Taussig shunt and 197 receiving the right ventricle-to-pulmonary artery shunt. The median stage II procedure hospital LOS was 8 days (IQR 6, 14), with no significant difference between shunt types. Hospital mortality was 4.3%, and transplantation occurred in 0.8% of cases. Longer LOS was associated with center, longer post-Norwood LOS, non-elective timing of the stage II procedure, and pulmonary artery stenosis. Non-elective stage II, moderate or greater atrioventricular valve regurgitation, and atrioventricular valve repair were risk factors for in-hospital death.

Interpretation: Shunt type did not significantly affect stage II hospital LOS. Factors such as Norwood LOS, pulmonary artery stenosis, and non-elective stage II procedure were associated with longer LOS. The trial was registered under [Trial Registration Number].
